summary: This is an FBI FD-302 interview summary of Cherie Quigley, a former Deutsche Bank employee in the anti-financial crime unit, conducted on October 10, 2019. Quigley describes her role in transaction monitoring, the bank's systems for detecting suspicious activity, and her team's handling of alerts and Politically Exposed Person (PEP) reviews. She discusses specific cases involving Jared Kushner and Jeffrey Epstein, noting Epstein's attorney's cash withdrawals and the bank's reputational concerns about Epstein.

persons.name: Cherie Quigley
persons.role: Former Deutsche Bank/DWS employee in anti-financial crime unit
persons.context: The interviewee who managed a transaction monitoring team at Deutsche Bank and later DWS. She discusses the bank's processes for handling suspicious activity alerts and PEP reviews, including cases related to Jared Kushner and Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Wayne Salit
persons.context: Quigley reported to him at Deutsche Bank. She discussed concerns about Bitcoin, marijuana transactions, and Jeffrey Epstein's relationship with the bank with him.

persons.name: Maura Liconte
persons.role: Quigley's later supervisor at Deutsche Bank
persons.context: Quigley eventually reported to her at Deutsche Bank.

persons.name: Tim McNeil
persons.context: Maura Liconte reported to him.

persons.name: Keith Falconer
persons.context: Wayne Salit reported to him in Germany.

persons.name: Ying Wang
persons.role: Team member under Quigley in New York
persons.context: Worked on Quigley's team, initially assigned all PEP cases. Was overwhelmed with work and placed 102 PEPs in a deferred status, which caused an issue raised by Tammy McFadden.

persons.name: Kripa Aryal
persons.context: Was on Quigley's New York team, later became a yoga instructor.

persons.name: Robert Wang
persons.role: Team member under Quigley in New York
persons.context: Was on Quigley's New York team.

persons.name: Michelle Gabriel
persons.role: Team member under Quigley in Jacksonville
persons.context: Was on Quigley's Jacksonville, FL team.

persons.name: Tammy McFadden
persons.role: Team member under Quigley in Jacksonville
persons.context: A difficult employee who Quigley trusted the least. McFadden raised an issue about a Jared Kushner transaction and made a 'big stink' about Ying Wang's handling of deferred PEP reviews.

persons.name: Danya Friedman
persons.role: Team member under Quigley in Jacksonville
persons.context: Was on Quigley's Jacksonville, FL team.

persons.name: Kevin Wilson
persons.role: Team member under Quigley in Jacksonville
persons.context: Was on Quigley's Jacksonville, FL team.

persons.name: Horace Swafford
persons.context: Was later added to Quigley's team.

persons.name: Patricia Melo
persons.context: Was later added to Quigley's team.

persons.name: Clarissa Delafuente
persons.context: May have set the initial parameters for the PRIME transaction monitoring system.

persons.name: Jared Kushner
persons.context: Subject of a PEP review by Tammy McFadden involving a $4,000 transaction to Russia from a corporate account. The recipient was determined to be a software developer.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deutsche Bank client whom Quigley described as 'a pig.' She noted his accounts paid women who appeared to be models of legal age and that his attorney made large weekly cash withdrawals. She expressed reputational concerns about the bank's relationship with him.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who withdrew $7,500 in cash each week from Epstein's accounts, prompting the filing of a Suspicious Activity Information Form (SAIF).

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Became a 'covered client' at Deutsche Bank, requiring special access to view his profile. Quigley had to review all relationships to him.

persons.name: Cacioppo Carmen Anthony
persons.context: FBI agent who drafted the FD-302 interview summary.

persons.name: Wintonick Steven G
persons.context: FBI agent who drafted the FD-302 interview summary.

connections.description: Quigley reported to Salit at Deutsche Bank and later at DWS. She discussed work concerns and specific client issues like Jeffrey Epstein with him.
Quigley managed McFadden but did not get along with her, trusted her the least, and described her as difficult, narcissistic, and manipulative.
Quigley managed Wang, initially assigned her all PEP cases, and later acknowledged cutting her slack when she was overwhelmed.
Indyke was Epstein's attorney and made weekly $7,500 cash withdrawals from Epstein's Deutsche Bank accounts, which triggered a SAIF filing.
Quigley was aware of Epstein as a Deutsche Bank client, saw transactions from his accounts paying women, and discussed the reputational risk of his relationship with the bank.
McFadden performed a PEP review on a transaction from a Kushner corporate account sending $4,000 to Russia.
McFadden did not like Wang and made a 'big stink' about Wang's handling of deferred PEP reviews.
Liconte reported to McNeil at Deutsche Bank.
Salit reported to Falconer in Germany.

events.title: FBI Interview of Cherie Quigley
events.description: FBI agents interview Cherie Quigley at her residence in Middletown, NJ, regarding her work in transaction monitoring at Deutsche Bank and DWS.

events.title: SAIF Filed on Darren Indyke
events.description: A Suspicious Activity Information Form (SAIF) was filed by Quigley's team on Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Darren Indyke, due to his weekly $7,500 cash withdrawals.

events.title: PEP Review of Jared Kushner Transaction
events.description: Tammy McFadden reviewed a transaction involving $4,000 sent to Russia from a Jared Kushner corporate account. The review involved checking a GoDaddy website and contacting a relationship manager.

events.title: Deutsche Bank Tries to Terminate Epstein Relationship
events.description: Deutsche Bank attempted to terminate its banking relationship with Jeffrey Epstein before details about him hit the papers.

events.title: New York Times Article About McFadden
events.description: A New York Times article was published containing allegations about Tammy McFadden, which surprised Quigley.

keyFacts: Cherie Quigley, a Deutsche Bank/DWS anti-financial crime manager, stated her team filed a Suspicious Activity Information Form (SAIF) on Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Darren Indyke, for weekly $7,500 cash withdrawals.

Quigley recalled seeing Epstein's Deutsche Bank accounts paying women who appeared to be models of legal age and expressed that she and her supervisor thought the bank should not do business with Epstein due to reputational risk.
Deutsche Bank attempted to terminate its relationship with Jeffrey Epstein before negative publicity about him emerged.
Quigley's team conducted a Politically Exposed Person (PEP) review on a transaction from a Jared Kushner corporate account involving $4,000 sent to Russia.
Quigley described a contentious relationship with employee Tammy McFadden, whom she trusted the least, and noted Deutsche Bank advised all employees not to speak with the press.
